title: 107_s244
content: The Act may be cited as the "Justice for the Victims of Pan Am 103 Act of 2001". Congress findings: 270, including 189 Americans, killed in Pan Am Flight 103 bombing over Lockerbie, Scotland. Scottish court found Libyan origin of plot, convicted Abdel Basset Ali Megrahi. Megrahi member of Libyan intelligence service. The United Nations Security Council imposed economic sanctions on Libya until they extradited the Pan Am 103 suspects and cooperated with the court. Libya must pay compensation to the victims' families and end support for terrorism to have sanctions permanently lifted. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "Government of Libya" includes any agency or instrumentality of the Government of Libya. The term "United States assistance" includes assistance under various acts such as the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 and the Arms Export Control Act. SEC. 4. SENSE OF CONGRESS. The sense of Congress condemns Libya and Gaddafi for supporting terrorism, specifically the bombing of Pan Am 103. Libya should apologize, compensate victims' families, and accept responsibility. Other countries should maintain sanctions until Libya complies. The President should urge the UN Security Council to keep sanctions on Libya until they apologize, compensate victims' families, and end support for terrorism. Congress should be consulted on policy towards Libya. The United States policy towards Libya is to oppose the removal of sanctions until specific conditions are met, as outlined in section 7. The covered sanctions include those specified in various laws such as the International Security and Development Cooperation Act of 1981 and the Iran and Libya Sanctions Act of 1996. SEC. 6 prohibits US assistance to Libya until the President certifies conditions in SEC. 7 are met. SEC. 7 outlines conditions that must be met for US assistance to Libya, including resolving cases of US nationals affected by Libyan terrorism, providing compensation for Pan Am 103 victims, issuing a public apology and accepting responsibility for the bombing, and ending support for international terrorism.
